awd_titl_txt: Making Decisions about Socioscientific Issues in Multidisciplinary Post-secondary Learning Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Undergraduate students must be prepared to examine complex scientific issues and make socially responsible decisions. As citizens, students need to be informed and empowered to make choices that have local and global impacts. The traditional approach to science education is to focus on content knowledge and disciplinary practices. However, as many researchers have pointed out, the knowledge and methods of science alone are insufficient to prepare students to make well-reasoned decisions - they must also learn decision-making skills. In addition, more than ever, employers are calling for recent college graduates who have not only knowledge, but the ability to apply their knowledge to complex issues and problem solving. The project will be conducted within the context of a large-enrollment, required introductory course, SCIL (Science Literacy) 101, for all majors in the University of Nebraska-Lincoln College of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources. In the course, students will learn about complex food, water, energy, and health issues and practice decision-making using a tool based on normative models of decision-making. Because the course is required it is anticipated that it will impact up to 1800 STEM students over the course of three years. The project will advance the theoretical and practical understanding of how to teach decision-making skills in science courses and impact the future STEM workforce as well as empower citizens to make high-quality decisions about complex personal, professional, local, and global issues.
 
The overall goal of this foundational, design-based research project is to refine a model undergraduate course to support students' science literacy through decision-making practice, and to evaluate the impact of the course on students' decision-making and reasoning about socioscientific issues, which involve facets of both science and society. The barriers for students will be articulated by examining how they make high quality decisions, for example: how well do they understand and apply scientific information to decision-making; and how well do they evaluate tradeoffs among options for solving the problem? Additionally, the project team will investigate if practices learned in a structured classroom context transfer to an unstructured setting when students make a decision about a new socioscientific issue. The products of this research include both new theory and new practice, including: a transportable evidence-based model course and its associated materials for teaching decision-making about socioscientific issues, including assessment rubrics; and a new theoretical framework based in the decision-sciences and behavior psychology that describes students' challenges in the decision-making process.

por.por_cntn:
As a result of the Decision-making about socioscientific issues in multidisciplinary postsecondary learning environments, an Engaged Student Learning (Exploration and Design tier) project, we accomplished two goals: 1) we refined a model post-secondary multidisciplinary science course (SCIL 101: Science and Decision-making for a Complex World, hereafter, SCIL101) that supports students? science literacy, and 2) we evaluated the course impact on students? decision-making about socioscientific issues through foundational, design-based research.

Broader impacts: in our work we sought to change the focus of science education from context knowledge and science practices, to science literacy as defined by supporting students in using science in their decision-making about complex real-world socioscientific issues. We did this by creating a model course that is focused on science literacy skills outcomes such as finding, evaluating and applying science evidence to decision-making and using a tradeoffs analysis to consider how best to achieve desired outcomes. We documented increases in students? civic attitudes and skills, socioscientific reasoning, library self-efficacy and argumentation skills after taking the class, which provides an evidence-basis for the SCIL 101 classroom model as a way to support students? science literacy. We widely disseminated evidence-based learning materials through academic journals, teaching-focused practitioner journals, workshops, academic and non-academic conferences and meetings, and other outlets. The teaching materials include a framework for students to use a structured decision-making model to apply evidence to their reasoning about how to solve complex socioscientific issues, as well as assessment rubrics. This project also had direct impacts in that between Fall 2017 and Fall 2021, there were 3047 undergraduate students who enrolled in the SCIL 101 course, where approximately 56% of the incoming students in CASNR have financial need as determined by federal student aid and a high proportion are first-generation students. There were seven faculty members and three post-docs who acted as instructors of the course. There were 61 graduate students, 43 undergraduate students and 7 post-doctoral researchers who served as Learning Assistants for the course.  

Intellectual merit: Our work provides a fundamental understanding of how undergraduates reason during decision-making about complex SSIs and the role of science education in improving student science literacy. Our research is one of the few science education studies that directly address the practices of decision-making. Through qualitative and quantitative data, we described student challenges in decision-making and created theoretical frameworks for students? application of evidence to socioscientific issues and for levels of sophistication in decision-making practices. Additionally, our research lays the groundwork for future assessments on decision-making, which currently has no widely-accepted assessment standard. The work achieved in this project helped to lay the groundwork for additional current NSF projects, and future grant proposals.
